abstract.p: D Nurkse article on poetry workshop he conducts at Island Academy, one of three public schools on Rikers Island; sample poems; photo (M)

block.p: RIKERS ISLAND is not one prison but a world of prisons -- scores of buildings identified by cryptic acronyms, separated by ribbon wire, linked by a fleet of rickety Department of Correction buses; between jail and jail, you see nothing, except stray cats, sea gulls and the occasional hawk.

The population seems almost exclusively black, Latino and poor; and disturbingly young. Many are ''substance abusers,'' a term that can mask a host of unspoken catastrophes. One kid's fidgets may be the result of crack; another's college plans froze when he was caught with marijuana. ''I came to Rikers to meet my father,'' one young prisoner told me proudly.

RIKERS ISLAND is not one prison but a world of prisons -- scores of buildings identified by cryptic acronyms, separated by ribbon wire, linked by a fleet of rickety Department of Correction buses; between jail and jail, you see nothing, except stray cats, sea gulls and the occasional hawk.

The population seems almost exclusively black, Latino and poor; and disturbingly young. Many are ''substance abusers,'' a term that can mask a host of unspoken catastrophes. One kid's fidgets may be the result of crack; another's college plans froze when he was caught with marijuana. ''I came to Rikers to meet my father,'' one young prisoner told me proudly.

In 1998 I was hired to lead poetry workshops at Island Academy, one of three public schools on Rikers Island. The first time I taught creative writing there, I suggested a broad theme: ''My Life.'' I watched a teenager smooth out a piece of paper and write those words at the top, then his street name, then his name. An hour later he was still writing.

Here are a few poems by teenagers at Rikers, reproduced by permission of Island Academy. Because it is the policy of the city's Departments of Education and Correction to maintain the confidentiality of the students, only their first names are used.
What I Don't See
Cuticle in my pupil
in a dispute when it's futile
One finger on a trigger
Stomach full of liquor
Trying to run around the world
like a bird when it's winter
Destroying a whole tree just to make a splinter
My center is being a mentor for my younger genders
while the necromancy of the ghetto enhances me
I write down life frantically
When you're too tired
put to sleep your sanity
and awake your fantasy
Kariem
One Phone Call
If I had one phone call
I would call my father from the dead
and pray that I don't get shot in the head
and pray that I could see him sleeping in mother's bed
and pray that he was never dead
Andrew
My Life
My life is hard and I don't know why I live this way
I've seen death between my eyes
My moms kicked me out when I was 9 years old
I was roaming the streets like a soldier at war.
The streets are so dark and so lonely
sometimes I tremble, sometimes I cry.
I still ask myself why God wanted it to be this way.
I feel God put me in this world to be a soldier,
to carry my crown until the day I die.
Pedro
The Maze
My train of thoughts moves faster than the speed of light.
It moves so fast it's hard to catch, like a rat in a maze,
and it drives me insane.
It is the maze of my brain, it's not hard to get lost in my
thoughts.
And once I get lost, I don't want to be found.
I just wander the rooms of my mind,
always looking out the windows but never there.
What's behind the next corner?
Is it the tangerine trees and marmalade sky
or the two sheets before I lost my mind?
Whatever it is, it's no surprise because I put it there
before I sealed the maze shut.
Now it's just a matter of pulling and throwing things
in and out the windows and understanding
the train of thought in my maze.
Next stop: Understanding!
Omar
AM
At night I lie on my bed wondering
if people are thinking of me
or have I been forgotten?
I am just a number in this hell-hole
and a number I will be
if I'm forgotten
Just the thought of me on someone's mind
gives me chills
Anthony
The Story
What's the story?
Whose story to believe?
His-story, her-story
or the story of the seeds,
the seeds that the breeze
has carried afar
across land and sea
or Her-story of the stars,
Her-story of the land and sea
the seeds breeze across,
or His-story of His glory
and His death upon a cross?
My-story is: their story
has only got me confused.
There are so many stories
of men and their glory.
The true story
is harder to choose.
Terrence
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RIKERS ISLAND D. Nurkse is a former poet laureate of Brooklyn. His most recent book of poetry is ''The Fall.''
